Well, it is confirmed. No local players, separatists, Russia and Ukraine, have wanted these elections. Nobody is satisfied with the status quo, but nobody is willing to compromise. Only the West wanted the elections in belief they  settle things. Unfortunately not quite. THE good part is that the Minsk agreements did bring some respite in this conflict. AT the same time, they froze hostilities not to be resolved for quite some time.

The leader of the Donetsk People's Republic suspended his decree on holding elections slated for November 6. DONETSK (Sputnik) — The head of the Donetsk People's Republic (DPR) has halted his decree to hold local elections on November 6, Alexander Zakharchenko's spokesperson told RIA Novosti on Wednesday. "The head halted the decree on holding elections scheduled for November 6," Zakharchenko's spokesperson said. Also on Wednesday, head of the neighboring Lugansk People's Republic Ukraine Igor Plotnitsky issued a decree postponing local elections scheduled for November 6 until further notice. Holding local elections in Donbass is one of the key stages of Ukrainian conflict settlement in accordance with the Minsk agreements signed in February 2015.
https://sputniknews.com/politics/201610261046763920-donetsk-republic-halts-elections/

"The President of Ukraine said that the Russian side agreed with the need to introduce armed OSCE police mission.
In the Donetsk and Luhansk People's Republic opposed the introduction of the OSCE mission. "Interfax" said the envoy Vladislav LC Dane.
According to him, the introduction of the OSCE mission in Donbass armed technically difficult to implement. "To date, this is not necessary We are categorically against also is not practicable from the technical side -.. Then need another mission and another mandate of the current mission is of a purely civilian nature of a word, it will be possible to implement this initiative is unlikely.." - He said, . 
Deputy commander of the operational command of the self-proclaimed Donetsk People's Republic Eduard Eduard Basurin also sees no possibility to implement such initiatives. "Firstly the OSCE mission in Donbass no military units mission observation and civil Secondly, the introduction here of police or other foreign military mission would be contrary to the Minsk agreements, which clearly point to the inadmissibility of the presence of foreigners with guns in the Donbass..", - Said, he. President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko on the results of the talks held in Berlin in "Norman format" said the leaders of the "Normandy format" agreed that in the Donbass will be put armed OSCE mission, which is to ensure that the preparations for the local elections in the region."

DPR authorities will discuss date of local elections with international mediators
02:01, 12.10.2016Politics The date of the elections to the local authorities on the territory of the Donetsk People's Republic will be discussed with the international mediators, said the Head of the DPR Alexander Zakharchenko.     ‘As for a specific date, we will discuss it with the international mediators, and first of all with Russia. Of course, we can not wait forever, sooner or later, Kiev will have to comply with the Minsk Agreements. There is no alternative to this. If they can not do it on their own, let them ask for help of their supervisors from across the ocean. Americans ... will make them adopt the necessary laws in the Ukrainian parliament. And then we’ll do everything ourselves,’ said Zakharchenko. Zakharchenko also added that after the preliminary public vote, the Republican authorities are fully prepared for holding the local elections.     ‘Now, after we successfully held the primaries, we can safely look ahead and declare that we are ready to hold the elections to the local authorities at any time ... So now it's up to the Ukrainian side. It is Kiev that slows down the process and demonstrates the lack of political will to implement the Minsk Agreements and move towards a political settlement of our conflict with them,’ concluded the Head of the DPR.
http://novorossia.vision/en/news/vlasti-dnr-obsudiat-datu-mestnykh-vyborov-s-mezhdunarodnymi-posrednikami/ Donetsk, Oct 3 – DAN. The yesterday’s vote is meant to pave the way for the anticipated local elections in the region, and strengthen the DPR’s developing political system.

It looks there is a tendency to significantly increase chances for the elections based on the fact of the recent primaries. IMHO not quite. The Donetsk elections is just one of the cards in a game played between Russia and the West. The separatists are dependent on Russia and the fact of the primaries was just  to say "If it is needed, we can organize and hold any elections in two-three weeks, with election campaign and all". The elections is another matter - it is part of the Minsk agreement. And so far, the Minsk process was moving in Russia's interests. So, no elections were needed. But it all changed as the big picture changed: Alleppo and, to lesser extent, MH17 investigation. The most recent events - cancellation of Putin's visit to Paris and Germany's talk to impose new sanctions linked to Syria - put Minsk progress on jeopardy from Russia's point of view. So, to show the West its power now Russia can push for the Donetsk elections to embarrass the West, and Germany and France, in particular. Nothing prevents Russia then to get back to its previous position if Minsk process is resumed at earnest. The elections are scheduled for November 6, if I remember correctly. The preparation for them should start at least two weeks in advance. So for a week or so, I'll keep this 30% chance. If nothing is announced. I may revert to my previous position.
"Primaries are not elections" is what I think GJO may say. EDIT:  sorry for the double post.  When I clicked on "My Forecasts" my earlier forecast didn't appear, so I reposted.

http://dan-news.info/en/society/in-the-run-up-to-primaries-donetsk-is-getting-ready-to-vote.html As was described in the above link, on Oct 2nd primaries were held. https://sputniknews.com/europe/201610061046055170-donetsk-local-elections/ "On October 2, mayoral and administrative elections were held in Donetsk and Lugansk. They became a political and media message that the self-proclaimed republics sent to the international community," he told Sputnik Italy in an interview. "The journalist noted that the elections were held in accordance with international standards: "All the opportunities have been given to us, international observers: I visited seven different polling stations, could freely take pictures and shoot video, talk with the staff and with the voters. I have not noted any violations." Eliseo Bertolasi also shared his feelings on the overall mood during the elections: "I was impressed by the enthusiasm of the voters. In Italy, politicians are most afraid of low turnout; and here it was a whole celebration, not just a measure." " . . . For Donetsk these elections, despite being local, were of great importance, the journalist believes. "They showed the world that the new republic, though still not having fully recovered, was able to organize and conduct the elections in accordance with international safety and transparency standards," Bertolasi concluded.

Interesting explanation from what seems to be a pro-separatist website: "Primary elections in the Lugansk People’s Republic – an observer’s account Oct 3, 2016 15:33     
On the 2nd of October the people of the Lugansk People’s Republic headed to the polls to cast their vote in the primary elections. According to the Minks agreement, Ukraine should enact laws which would enable the Donbass republics, Lugansk People’s Republic (LPR) and Donetsk People’s Republic (DPR), to hold local elections in their territories. Such laws have not yet been passed and Ukraine has officially signaled that it does not plan to respect the agreement. Due to the circumstances, a suggestion was made by two social movements in the LPR, Peace to Lugansk and the Lugansk Economic Union, that limited non-binding primary elections would be held instead of binding elections. The primary elections have the full support of the official LPR government, but are completely funded and organized by the social movements. According to the Oleg Akimov, the Chairman of the Trade Union Federation of LPR and deputy of the national Council of LPR, the primary elections are principally held to evaluate and test the electoral system, to get a feel for the will of the people and to demonstrate that the LPR is able to hold elections according to the OSCE’s standards." The negotiations process is working again. That means that there is a glimmer of hope of an overall settlement. To be honest, I do not think it will happen this year - Ukraine is supposed to go for some unpopular measures to give the separatists enough legitimacy. Still, some hope...

So, let's summarize. Elections in Donetsk were postponed not even once, but this time it looks different. This time the DNR announced two step system: first, primaries on October 2, and then the real elections (which in July were previously scheduled on November 6). Registration from September 13 to 17 led to more than 1000 (1095) candidates. http://riafan.ru/556571-doneck-gotovitsya-k-praimeriz-v-dnr-nachalas-predvybornaya-agitaciya (sorry, in Russian). The election commissions and boundaries are set up,  It looks eventual number of local parliament seats is 100 (at least it is the current number of seats in DNR: it’s also 50 in LNR, but I am not sure do primaries include the other separatist republic or not). So it is roughly 10 to 1 candidates for primaries filter, which is quite a good competition.  In the last election two parties divided the parliament. So could we state we may expect democracy to win on November 6? Some doubts remain though. Firstly, why to have elections at all? In 2014 the parliaments in DNR and LNR (and actually, oddly, prime ministers as well) were elected for 4-year terms. Their time is not up yet. But these elections are part of the Minsk agreement between France, Germany, Ukraine and Russia, which were approved by separatists as well. Ukraine was supposed to change their laws and Constitution to accommodate separatists, then to have election under UKRANIAN laws, with control over borders going back to Ukraine. Ukraine does not want changes in the Constitution, as they would legitimize at least some of the demands of separatists who are considered terrorists. Hence, Ukraine talks about lack of safety there and “occupation” by Russia. Russia wants a thorn in Ukrainian side, one way or another, and Donbas government under their full control (one way or another). They want constitutional changes to incapacitate Ukraine. And, most of all, they want this as a part of settlement with the West. There is no real need for Russia for these elections to proceed without the latter.  So these elections are absurd without recognition by Ukraine. There have been some movements for grand settlement between Russia and the West – Putin talked to Merkel, Obama and Hollande on G20 sidelines, Germans and the French visited Kiev, but so far nothing out of it.  So despite all these pronouncements, I personally do not think  this is legit. Just for the show… But who am I? I have been wrong before :)

US says won’t recognize outcome of Russian elections in Crimea The United States has denounced upcoming Russian parliamentary elections planned for the Crimean peninsula, saying it "does not recognize the legitimacy" of the process. "The United States does not recognize the legitimacy, and will not recognize the outcome, of the Russian Duma elections planned for Russian-occupied Crimea on September 18th," State Department spokesman John Kirby said in a statement issued on Friday. Two-and-a-half years after the reunification of Crimea with the Russian mainland, residents of the peninsula are getting ready to vote on Sunday in their first elections to elect members of Duma, Russia's national parliament.

But even the results of the candidate registration,  cutoff for which which was yesterday, was not publicized. 100+ candidates is not enough for real competition in primaries. Which means for me that it was all posturing. I'll wait till October 2 when I may be forced to reassess its seriousness. Now going back to my previous estimates...

Political parties active in the DPR include Donetsk Republic, the Communist Party of the Donetsk People's Republic, Free Donbass, and the New Russia Party. Donetsk Republic and the Communists endorsed Prime Minister Alexander Zakharchenko's candidature for the premiership in 2014. In these elections the Communists were banned from participating independently because they had "made too many mistakes" in their submitted documents. In the internationally unrecognized elections held by the People's Republics in 2014, Donetsk Republic gained a majority in the DPR People's Soviet with 68.53% of the vote and 68 seats. Free Donbass, including candidates from the Russian-nationalist extremist New Russia Party, won 31.65% of the vote and 32 seats. On 6 October 2015 the DNR and LPR leadership postponed their planned elections to 21 February 2016. This happened 4 days after a Normandy four meeting in which it was agreed that the October 2015 Ukrainian local elections in LPR and DPR controlled territories would be held in accordance to the February 2015 Minsk II agreement. At the meeting President of France François Hollande stated that in order to hold these elections (in LPR and DPR controlled territories) it was necessary "since we need three months to organize elections" to held these elections in 2016. Also during the meeting it is believed that Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed to use his influence to not allow the DPR and Luhansk People's Republic election to take place on 18 October 2015 and 1 November 2015 On 18 April 2016 planned (organised by the DPR) local elections were postponed from 20 April to 24 July 2016. On 22 July 2016 the elections were again postponed to 6 November 2016.
-------
COMMENT: So many postponements, and no elections seem to take place without a nod from Vlad.

New development - separatists announced primaries on October 2 - http://www.ng.ru/cis/2016-09-09/1_dnr.html (in Russian, sorry) and started registering candidates.  In other circumstances this would mean 100% probability of elections in November, but I doubt that. There is no actual need for these elections as they are part of the Minsk agreements, which are not working.  This is definitely a (Russian) move to attract attention of the West and placate the government of Ukraine as unwilling to do necessary steps to solve the problem. At this point though Russia wants to settle Ukraine problem by compromising on Syria (highest priority for the US and EU) and insisting on its terms on Ukraine. So far it did not work though there was some hope at G20. Hence, Russia yanks the chain...  The problem is that it is all a play,  a show of force. But sometimes the show leads to real steps... Increasing chances for elections...

Continuing https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/315609 -
Probability of a great bargain on Ukraine between Russia and the West in the question time frame is negligible. Putin did meet with Obama, Merkel and Hollande on G20 sidelines, but any outcome should be forthcoming very slowly. The West wants agreement with Russia on Syria, their priority. And Russia wants agreement on Ukraine, her priority. As there was no immediate change on Syria, most probably any changes on Ukraine will be even slower. No agreement - no need for elections. My personal opinion - I do not pretend to know The Truth
The Ukraine has no incentive to hold or recognize elections and Russia has not incentive to remove its troops.
I have been sloppy today. Correcting...

As I argued before - https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/310102 - neither Ukraine, nor separatists want elections and the latter actually may happen only if there is some grand bargain struck between Russia and the West (which was the main force to include them into the Minsk agreements). Now there are signs that it may be happening: Putin's posturing after Crimea "terrorist attack" and Poroshenko's talk with Kazakhstan's Nazarbayev may show some movement to a new compromise. Most probably we'll have more data after G20 meeting or rather meetings of Putin with Merkel, Hollande and maybe Obama. It will become even clearer when Rada (Ukrainian parliament) comes back on September 7 and sets it agenda. Of course, the main problem is that you need only Putin's decision on one side, but on the other side we have a messy democracy-oligarchy in Ukraine where Poroshenko may not have enough support in parliament even if he wants to make bold decisions, which are good enough for solving this conflict. Still, there is a glimmer of hope... I'll put it at 3%.

No Election - No money for Ukraine, maybe they will try to organize elections

Let’s start with the basics: the election was actually scheduled for November 6 this year (before it had been scheduled in April, then July). But who wants this election as part of Minsk agreements to happen at all? Donetsk and Luhansk authorities do not want it as it will permit the “fascist” Ukraine government to come to their turf and after the election they will need to cede control of the border to Ukraine and perhaps share their power with some elected officials. Why bother as they have all the power already?
Ukraine’s government does not want it as the Minsk agreement forces them to have unpopular measures for decentralization and constitutional reform to pass through Rada. It uses this situation as an excuse for struggling economy.
Russia does not want it as militarized Donbass is playing a role of a stumbling block for Ukraine to move closer to the West, join EU and NATO.
Only the West wants the election in belief that a democratic process settles all scores and leads to peace and prosperity. Can we conclude that probability of elections is zero?
Not quite. The West does hold some cards: Ukraine depends on their support. And they say that Obama wants to settle Ukraine situation before he leaves the office. On the other hand, Putin may be open to a bargain – non-aligned Ukraine, end of sanctions, some acknowledgement of Russia as a great power… Donbass requires a stream of money and arms at the time of economic crisis. As Donbass almost completely depends on Russia, they will do whatever Russia says: all disagreeable leaders were eliminated one by one.
My problem with this scenario is that it is not the first priority either for Americans, or for Europeans.
Of course, Donetsk and Luhansk can have elections to legitimize their power and stick it to the Man (in Kiev). But probability of that is low too – no real opposition in their respective turfs.
So unless there is some movement to a great bargain between Russia and the West, I put probability of elections at zero. I may regret that.

"Ukraine marks a quarter century of independence from the Soviet Union on Wednesday, and Vladimir Putin’s idea of a birthday gift is to mass troops on its border. This could be a gambit to force a new round of diplomatic concessions from the West—or the prelude to another war. The Kremlin’s buildup includes deploying the S-400 air-defense system in Crimea and air and naval assets in the Black Sea, while conducting tank exercises in the Russian-occupied strip of Moldovan territory called Transnistria. In May the Kremlin formed a new motorized rifle division in Russia’s western Rostov region, which borders Ukraine’s separatist regions of Donetsk and Luhansk. Mr. Putin has also refused to grant the Kiev government control over its eastern borders, as he was required to do under last year’s Minsk II Agreement. As a result, he can reinforce his proxies in eastern Ukraine with troops, materiel and missiles of the sort that brought down Malaysia Airlines Flight 17 in 2014. Then there is the Kremlin’s rhetoric. Moscow earlier this month accused Ukraine of dispatching saboteurs to Crimea in an attempt to destabilize the peninsula ahead of Russian parliamentary “elections” next month. The accusation suggests a classic Russian disinformation operation. Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko has said a military mobilization is possible and warned the West not to rule out a “full-scale Russian invasion” of his country. That makes Washington’s blasé reaction all the more dangerous. The Pentagon believes the Russian buildup is a routine drill, though drills have been used historically as covers for invasion. Meanwhile, Vice President Joe Biden urged both sides to show restraint in a call Friday with Mr. Poroshenko, as if Kiev is guilty of any provocation except self-defense. President Obama has refused to provide Ukraine with the kinds of defensive arms that might deter the Russians. All of this recalls Russia’s invasion of Georgia in August 2008, which took place as another American President was about to leave office. History may not repeat itself, but the West has given Mr. Putin little reason for pause if he does have designs on more Ukraine territory this year." 1. Escalating violence:  Ceasefire violations in eastern Ukraine have reached their highest level in months, with violence again reaching "worrying levels," the chief OSCE monitor said 28 April 2016. "During the past weeks, the OSCE has registered the highest number of ceasefire violations in months," Ertugrul Apakan said, calling for the warring parties to show "visible and decisive" action to restore the truce. An article that appeared in July 2016 in the Nezavisimoye Voyennoye Obozreniye — a publication which frequently features material reflecting the official position of the Russian authorities — was headlined: "Ukraine has become Russia's strategic adversary: Moscow does not exclude the possibility of a major war." Alexander Golts, an independent Russian military analyst who is a visiting researcher at Sweden's University of Uppsala, saids it is not surprising that Ukraine is now openly being referred to in Russia as an "enemy". "It is clear that Ukraine now is anything but a state friendly to Russia," he told VOA's Russian service 04 July 2016. "In and of itself, the Ukrainian army, of course, is not a strategic problem for Russia. In Moscow, however, they are guided by phantom scenarios, in which Ukraine will eventually become part of NATO. One of Russia's excuses for its actions in Crimea and the Donbas is that it was acting to prevent Ukraine's possible entry into the North Atlantic alliance." Ukraine and Russia were locked in a war of words 11 Augst2016 over the Kremlin’s claim that Kyiv infiltrated trained saboteurs into Crimea tasked with targeting “critical infrastructure” — an alleged mission Russian President Vladimir Putin is now citing as the reason for his decision to pull out of scheduled peace talks in Normandy. Ukrainian officials say the sabotage mission is pure “fantasy,” arguing the Kremlin is likely to use it as a pretext for a major escalation of the two-year-long conflict in east Ukraine, where Moscow-backed forces were occupying a large chunk of the Donbas region, including the cities of Donetsk and Luhansk. By August 2016, the conflict had killed 10,000 people since it began in April 2014. While casualties have continued at a much reduced level since spring 2015, by mid-2016 both sides returned to using heavy artillery, including howitzers and ‘Grad’ multiple rocket launchers. In July 2016, the United Nations reported that eight died and 65 were injured. With escalating violence, it was getting much harder for international organizations to monitor the situation.  http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/russo-ukraine-2016.htm  2.
